item.title: Need help [Experienced coders preferably]
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

[quote=“Jc22493, post:30, topic:339670”][quote author=The Unholy link=topic=436049.msg3204484#msg3204484 date=1273670020]
Here’s my client.java on pastebin: http://pastebin.com/t5FZksy5
[/quote]

[quote author=Jc22493 link=topic=436049.msg3204125#msg3204125 date=1273620423]
What you have:

public void performAction() { // Over 64kb of code here. }

Change it to:

[code=java]public void performAction() {
// 32kb of code here.
}

public void performAction2() {
// 32kb of code here also.
}[/code]

What you have:

if (conditionIsMet) { performAction(); }

Change it to:

if (conditionIsMet) { performAction(); performAction2(); }
[/quote][/quote]No. If he does it that way, it will still call the second method even if the packet has been identified and handled coorectly. He needs to add the call to the second method inside the first method, so that if the first method handles the packet and returns, then the second method will not be called.

[quote=“Davidi2, post:25, topic:339670”]Ok, your problem is that each method is only allowed 64kb of space. You need to split it up. Here is what I would do:

public method parseIncommingPackets() { //Put 63kb of the code here parseIncommingPackets2(); } public method parseIncommingPackets2() { //Put 63kb of the code here parseIncommingPackets3(); }
So that it doesn’t go over the limit.

But make sure that you send any info that is in the first argument into the second method and so on.

If you post the entire thing on pastebin we could separate it for you.[/quote]

Read full topic

item.title: Need help [Experienced coders preferably]
item.dc:creator: @Svitkona Svitkona
item.description:
@Svitkona wrote:

declare a new void and add in it parts of the code, then invoke it in the original method like so:

public void parseIncomingPackets1() {
add code here
}
public void parseIncomingPackets2() {
add another part of the code here
}
public void parseIncomingPackets3() {
add the last part of the code here
}

then do private void parseIncomingPackets() { parseIncomingPackets1(); parseIncomingPackets2(); parseIncomingPackets3();
etc…

Read full topic

[quote=“Davidi2, post:25, topic:339670”]Ok, your problem is that each method is only allowed 64kb of space. You need to split it up. Here is what I would do:

public method parseIncommingPackets() { //Put 63kb of the code here parseIncommingPackets2(); } public method parseIncommingPackets2() { //Put 63kb of the code here parseIncommingPackets3(); }
So that it doesn’t go over the limit.

But make sure that you send any info that is in the first argument into the second method and so on.

If you post the entire thing on pastebin we could separate it for you.[/quote]

item.title: Need help [Experienced coders preferably]
item.dc:creator: @jc22493 Jc22493
item.description:
@jc22493 wrote:

What you have:

public void performAction() { // Over 64kb of code here. }

Change it to:

[code=java]public void performAction() {
// 32kb of code here.
}

public void performAction2() {
// 32kb of code here also.
}[/code]

What you have:

if (conditionIsMet) { performAction(); }

Change it to:

if (conditionIsMet) { performAction(); performAction2(); }

Read full topic

item.title: Need help [Experienced coders preferably]
item.dc:creator: @davidi2 Davidi2
item.description:
@davidi2 wrote:

Ok, your problem is that each method is only allowed 64kb of space. You need to split it up. Here is what I would do:

public method parseIncommingPackets() { //Put 63kb of the code here parseIncommingPackets2(); } public method parseIncommingPackets2() { //Put 63kb of the code here parseIncommingPackets3(); }
So that it doesn’t go over the limit.

But make sure that you send any info that is in the first argument into the second method and so on.

If you post the entire thing on pastebin we could separate it for you.

Read full topic
